title: White-throated hummingbird
text:
The white-throated hummingbird ("Leucochloris albicollis") is a species of <a href="hummingbird">hummingbird</a> in the family <a href="Trochilidae">Trochilidae</a>. It is the only member of the genus Leucochloris. It is found in north-eastern <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>, south-eastern <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="Paraguay">Paraguay</a>, and <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>. It is found in forest, woodland, parks and gardens. It is generally common, and therefore considered to be of <a href="Least%20Concern">least concern</a> by <a href="BirdLife%20International">BirdLife International</a>.
French ornithologist <a href="Louis%20Jean%20Pierre%20Vieillot">Louis Jean Pierre Vieillot</a> described the white-throated hummingbird in 1818 as "Trochilus albicollis". Its species name is derived from the Latin words "albus" "white" and "collum" "neck". <a href="Ludwig%20Reichenbach">Ludwig Reichenbach</a> erected the genus "Leucochloris" in 1854, deriving the name from the <a href="Ancient%20Greek">Ancient Greek</a> "leukos" "white" and "chloros" "green".
A 2014 genetic study found that it lay within the large genus "<a href="Amazilia">Amazilia</a>", and that it diverged around 5 million years ago from a lineage that gave rise to the <a href="green-and-white%20hummingbird">green-and-white hummingbird</a> ("Amazilia viridicauda"), <a href="white-bellied%20hummingbird">white-bellied hummingbird</a> ("A. chionogaster"), <a href="rufous-throated%20sapphire">rufous-throated sapphire</a> ("A. sapphirina"), <a href="gilded%20sapphire">gilded sapphire</a> ("Hylocharis chrysura"), <a href="sapphire-spangled%20emerald">sapphire-spangled emerald</a> ("A. lactea"), and <a href="glittering-throated%20emerald">glittering-throated emerald</a> ("A. fimbriata").
The white-throated hummingbird is 10–11·5 cm (4-4.5 in) long, with a distinctive white throat, belly and tail tips. The head, upperparts, wing coverts, chin and sides of neck are an iridescent green. The rest of the wings are purple-brown. It is unlikely to be confused with any other bird species. The male weighs 5–8 g (0.17–0.28 oz), while the female weighs around 4·5 g (0.16 oz).
The white-throated hummingbird is found in forest margins, marshy areas, shrubland and parks. It forages at both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads such as "<a href="Quesnelia%20testudo">Quesnelia testudo</a>" and "<a href="Tillandsia%20aeranthos">Tillandsia aeranthos</a>", as well as "<a href="Mendoncia%20velloziana">Mendoncia velloziana</a>", and "<a href="Siphocampylus%20sulfureus">Siphocampylus sulfureus</a>".
